rounds.response:
I'm currently sitting on  
[ AZURE-BTREE SUMMARY ]  
(Own stock after all moves up to the end of turn-4)

 Resource  Qty  Marginal-val  Stock-value
 Wheat       10       5          50
 Wood         7      11          77
 Sheep       25      13         325
 Brick        6      26         156
 Ore         17      35         595
-----------------------------------------
TOTAL VALUE ≈ 1 203  

Observations Players 0 has now twice “rejected no offer”, which means all he did so far is the initial 10 Sheep + 3 Ore → 8 Brick + 5 Wheat request that I already denied.  
Therefore Player 0 is very short on Brick and Wheat: he wants 8 more Brick and 5 more Wheat at the expense of Sheep/Ore.  
That leaves strong inference that he owns lots of Sheep & Ore but is exhausted on Brick & Wheat.  

Desirable moves for me  
- Offload some excess Sheep (I already have 25).  
- Acquire Wheat (only 10, value 5 is tiny).  
- Acquire Brick (only 6, but value 26 is high).  

I create a balanced counter-offer that  
- Gives Player 0 the Brick he asked for (8 -> 5 so he still progresses on Brick)  
- Lets him keep 2 of the 3 Wheat he requested, but compensates me with 2 Wood/Ore I value relatively lower.  

Offer making
[Offer: 5 Brick, 2 Sheep -> 7 Wheat, 2 Ore, 3 Wood]

rounds.response:
Total value in my stash right now:
• Wheat: 10 × 5  =  50  
• Wood :  7 × 11 =  77  
• Sheep: 25 × 13 = 325  
• Brick: 6 × 26 = 156  
• Ore  : 17 × 35 = 595  
Total = 1 203

I feel I’m short on brick (its marginal gain is $26 among the highest).  
Player 0 has already offered sheep + ore for brick + wheat and has 6 brick showing from earlier hints.  
Let me make a one-for-one brick-for-ore swap; it adds more value to my pile because each brick is $26 vs ore $35, but Player 0 values brick at 8 and ore at 35 so for him the surplus is huge.

[Offer: 1 Ore -> 1 Brick]

rounds.response:
I'm currently on Turn 6 and I want to find an offer that will add the most total value to my pile.

1. Re-calculate my present holdings (after no accepted trades so far):
   Wheat: 10 × 5  = 50  
   Wood:  7 × 11 = 77  
   Sheep: 25 × 13 = 325  
   Brick: 6 × 26 = 156  
   Ore:   17 × 35 = 595  
   Total value = 1 203  

2. Quick valuation ratios
   Brick/Ore ≈ 0.743  
   Wheat/Brick ≈ 0.192  
   Wood/Brick ≈ 0.423  
   Sheep/Brick ≈ 0.5  

3. High-value offers that help me
   I have extra Ore and I’d like Brick (biggest jump per unit).
   – 2 Ore for 3 Brick nets me 3·26 – 2·35 = 78 – 70 = +8 value.  
   – 3 Ore for 4 Brick nets +14.

Keeping the return conservative so Player 0 doesn’t feel squeezed:

[Offer: 2 Ore -> 3 Brick]

rounds.response:
Turn 8 summary  
So far almost every offer has been rejected and almost nothing has changed.  
I still want to improve the value of my hand; the resource that gives me the smallest **marginal gain** now is **Sheep** (13 value each, 25 copies), while the resource with the highest value is **Brick** (26 each).  
Therefore, I will give away a few Sheep in exchange for premium Brick, but at a fair rate to make it more likely Player 0 accepts.

Let me propose:

[Offer: 3 Sheep, 1 Wheat -> 2 Brick, 1 Ore]
